content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a really tough time sleeping lately. My mind just keeps racing at night about work and all the stress I'm under, and it’s starting to feel like it’s getting out of control. My partner suggested I talk to someone, so here I am, but I’m not really sure if this is going to help.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like sleep has been a struggle for you because of the stress you're carrying from work. It’s understandable that overwhelming thoughts can make it hard to rest. It's also a big step to explore talking about it, even if you’re unsure how this might help. What’s been weighing on your mind the most about work?

Honestly, I’m worried about losing my job. Things at work have been rough, and I feel like if layoffs happen, I’d be one of the first to go. If that happens, I don’t know how I’ll pay the bills and take care of my family. It’s like this constant pressure that doesn’t let up, and I just can’t shake it, especially at night.

That sounds incredibly heavy to carry, especially knowing how much you care about supporting your family. It makes sense that these worries would feel relentless and make it hard to step back at the end of the day. Facing uncertainty at work while trying to meet family responsibilities can feel like a huge challenge. How have you been managing all this pressure so far?

I’ve been trying to distract myself by scrolling through my phone at night, but honestly, I know it’s not helping. It just adds more stimulation and keeps me awake longer. I can’t seem to stop though—it’s like it’s better than sitting there trapped in my own thoughts.

It sounds like scrolling through your phone feels like a way to escape the thoughts that feel overwhelming, even though it’s not really helping you rest. Taking a break from those worries, even briefly, might feel easier in the moment than facing them directly. It’s clear you’re trying to find a way to cope with everything weighing on you. What’s been most challenging about trying to address those racing thoughts directly?

Honestly, when I try to address the racing thoughts, it just feels like I’m going in circles and making myself more anxious. It’s hard to see any solution or way out, so I end up avoiding it altogether. I feel stuck because I know avoiding it isn't helping, but facing it feels overwhelming too.

It sounds like you’re caught in a tough spot—you want to find relief, but facing the thoughts feels overwhelming, and avoiding them isn’t letting you move forward either. That sense of being stuck can feel really draining, especially when you're dealing with constant stress. It’s clear you’ve been trying to make sense of all this, even in the face of feeling overwhelmed. What would relief look like for you right now, even in small ways?

Honestly, I don’t even know. I guess if I could just get some sleep and wake up without feeling the weight of everything immediately, it might help. But even trying to think about how to get to that point feels impossible.

It sounds like even the idea of relief feels far away for you right now, but getting better sleep and feeling lighter when you wake up might be a small step toward easing some of the burden. It's completely understandable that imagining how to get there feels overwhelming, given everything you’re juggling. What’s one small thing that might make nights or mornings even slightly easier to handle?

It honestly feels like the only thing that might help is getting out of my own head, but I haven’t figured out how to do that yet. Maybe having some sort of routine at night could help, but I’m skeptical if it’d actually make a difference.

Considering a nighttime routine shows you’re open to exploring ways that might help, even if you're feeling unsure about the impact. It’s tough to believe things can change when you’ve been stuck in this cycle for a while. What kind of routine feels like it could help you settle into the night or feel calmer before bed?

I’m not really sure, honestly. Maybe something simple, like staying off my phone or trying to relax with something less overwhelming. But it’s hard to even think about what would actually work when my thoughts are so loud.

Thinking about staying off your phone or finding a calmer activity is a thoughtful step, especially if you're aiming to quiet those loud thoughts. Taking even small actions can feel like climbing uphill when stress is intense, but it's significant that you're exploring possibilities. What kind of relaxing activity might feel manageable or even slightly enjoyable for you at night?
I guess I could try reading a book or listening to some calming music. Something simple that doesn’t feel like too much effort. I’m not sure if it would work, but it might be worth a try.

Reading or listening to calming music sounds like a gentle and approachable idea, especially since it doesn’t require much effort while still helping you focus away from stressful thoughts. It's a step toward creating space for something soothing. How would it feel to try one of those activities tonight, even just for a few minutes?
I guess I could give it a try. It’s not going to fix everything, but maybe it’ll help a little. I’ll try to read for a bit before bed and see how it goes.

It’s great that you’re open to giving it a try, even if it doesn’t feel like it’ll fix everything right away. Taking that step, however small, is a meaningful way to break the cycle and explore what might help you rest more peacefully. Is there anything else about your sleep or stress that you’d like to talk through together before you give this a try?
Actually, I think I’m okay for now. I’ll give the reading a shot tonight and see how it goes. Thank you for listening and helping me sort through this—it was helpful just to talk it out.
